skos.definition: The most common movement disorder, characterized by bilateral postural and kinetic tremor, often affecting the hands and arms, typically without other neurological abnormalities, and often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
skos.scopeNote: Most common movement disorder; often confused with Parkinson disease; typically bilateral and symmetric

content.title: Essential Tremor
content.summary: Essential tremor is the most common movement disorder, characterized by action tremor (postural and kinetic) primarily affecting the hands, often with head or voice involvement. It improves with alcohol and worsens with stress. Unlike Parkinson disease, it is bilateral, symmetric, and lacks rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability. First-line treatments include propranolol and primidone.
key_points: Most common movement disorder; 10× more common than Parkinson disease
Action tremor (postural and kinetic); NOT rest tremor
Bilateral and relatively symmetric; hands most commonly affected
Often affects head ('no-no' or 'yes-yes' movement) and voice
Improves with alcohol (diagnostically useful but not therapeutic)
DBS of ventral intermediate nucleus (VIM) for refractory cases
content.statement: Essential tremor is a progressive, often familial tremor disorder that primarily affects the upper extremities during action. While sometimes called 'benign,' it can significantly impair quality of life. Understanding its distinction from Parkinson disease is crucial, as the pathophysiology, treatment, and prognosis differ substantially.

explanation.intuition: Think of essential tremor as the cerebellum's 'brake pedal' not working properly. When you try to hold something steady or reach for a target, the cerebellum normally dampens oscillations and provides smooth movement. In essential tremor, this dampening fails, causing a rhythmic oscillation that's worst during the action itself.
explanation.key_insight: The key distinction from Parkinson disease is the type of tremor: essential tremor is an ACTION tremor (present during movement and holding positions) while Parkinson tremor is a RESTING tremor (present at rest, suppressed during movement). Also, essential tremor is bilateral from the start, while Parkinson typically starts unilaterally.
explanation.technical_details: The underlying pathophysiology involves the cerebello-thalamo-cortical circuit. GABAergic dysfunction and abnormal oscillatory activity in the inferior olive and cerebellum generate the tremor. Postmortem studies show Purkinje cell loss and torpedoes (swollen axons). The VIM nucleus of the thalamus is the target for DBS because it is a key relay in this circuit.

definitions_glossary.action_tremor: Tremor occurring with voluntary muscle contraction; includes postural and kinetic tremor
definitions_glossary.postural_tremor: Tremor maintaining position against gravity (arms outstretched)
definitions_glossary.rest_tremor: Tremor present at complete rest; characteristic of Parkinson disease
definitions_glossary.intention_tremor: Tremor increasing near target (cerebellar lesions); not typical ET
definitions_glossary.propranolol: Non-selective beta-blocker; first-line treatment for essential tremor
definitions_glossary.primidone: Anticonvulsant metabolized to phenobarbital; first-line for ET
definitions_glossary.VIM_nucleus: Ventral intermediate nucleus of thalamus; DBS target for refractory tremor
definitions_glossary.deep_brain_stimulation: DBS - implanted electrodes delivering high-frequency stimulation to reduce tremor
definitions_glossary.autosomal_dominant: Inheritance pattern; ~50% of ET cases are familial
definitions_glossary.spiral_drawing: Archimedes spiral test; shows tremulous oscillations in ET
definitions_glossary.head_tremor: Titubation affecting head; 'no-no' or 'yes-yes' movements; common in ET
definitions_glossary.voice_tremor: Tremor of laryngeal muscles causing quavering voice
definitions_glossary.alcohol_response: Transient tremor improvement with alcohol; classic for ET (not therapeutic)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Abnormal oscillatory activity in the cerebello-thalamo-cortical loop generates the tremor. The inferior olive and cerebellar Purkinje cells show pathological changes. The tremor frequency is typically 4-12 Hz.

etiology.familial: 50% have positive family history; autosomal dominant inheritance
etiology.sporadic: 50% have no family history; likely multifactorial

pathophysiology.genetics: LINGO1, ETM1, ETM2 loci identified but account for minority of cases

symptoms: Difficulty drinking from cup, eating soup

modulating_factors.worsen: Stress, anxiety, caffeine, fatigue, certain medications

distinguishing_from_PD.essential_tremor: Bilateral, symmetric, action tremor, no bradykinesia/rigidity, may affect head/voice
distinguishing_from_PD.parkinson_disease: Unilateral at onset, rest tremor (pill-rolling), bradykinesia, rigidity, postural instability

clinical_diagnosis: Absence of other neurological signs (bradykinesia, rigidity, postural instability)
May have isolated head tremor without dystonic posturing
workup: Clinical examination (spiral drawing, finger-to-nose, outstretched arms)
MRI brain if atypical features (unilateral, sudden onset, other signs)
DaTscan if Parkinson disease is in differential (normal in ET)

first_line.contraindications: Asthma, bradycardia, heart block, uncompensated heart failure

first_line.side_effects: Sedation, ataxia at initiation (start 12.5-25 mg at bedtime)

pharmacologic.combination: Propranolol + primidone may have additive benefit

deep_brain_stimulation.indication: Medication-refractory tremor significantly affecting quality of life

prognosis.progression: Slowly progressive over years; may become disabling

learning_objectives: Differentiate essential tremor from Parkinson disease tremor
Identify the characteristic features of action tremor
Describe first-line pharmacologic treatments for essential tremor
Explain when DBS is indicated for tremor management
List factors that worsen and improve essential tremor
Recognize atypical features that warrant additional workup
clinical_pearls: Essential tremor is action (postural/kinetic); Parkinson is rest tremor
ET is bilateral and symmetric from onset; PD starts unilateral
Alcohol improvement is classic for ET (but don't use as treatment!)
Head tremor strongly favors ET over PD (head tremor rare in PD)
Start primidone very low (12.5 mg at bedtime) to avoid 'first dose phenomenon'
DaTscan is normal in ET, abnormal in PD - useful when diagnosis uncertain

common_question_stems: Elderly patient with bilateral hand tremor worse when drinking coffee
Comparing essential tremor vs Parkinson disease features
Patient asking about alcohol improving tremor
exam_tips: ET = action tremor, bilateral, may affect head/voice, alcohol helps
PD = rest tremor, starts unilateral, bradykinesia/rigidity, alcohol doesn't help

teaching_cases.scenario: 68-year-old woman with 10-year history of progressive hand shaking. Bilateral tremor holding coffee cup and writing. Head bobs. Tremor improves after glass of wine. No rigidity or bradykinesia.
teaching_cases.key_findings: Bilateral postural and kinetic tremor, head tremor, alcohol responsive, no parkinsonism
teaching_cases.management: Trial of propranolol starting 40 mg BID or primidone starting 25 mg QHS
